I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Pacific Private Sector Development Initiative (PSDI) provides advisory and capacity-
building  assistance  to  help  Pacific  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) improve their business enabling environments.1 This in turn supports 
inclusive,  private  sector-led  economic  growth.  The  three  consecutive  phases  of  PSDI 
implemented since 2007 have helped Pacific DMCs carry out reforms and introduce new policies 
to improve conditions for private sector development and investment, responding to related needs 
and opportunities as they evolved.2 PSDI has expended $60.83 million during the first three 
phases which funded more than 600 subprojects. This included grant cofinancing of $54.73 million 
from Australia and New Zealand which reflects the importance and value their governments place 
on introducing reforms and building capacity for private sector development in the Pacific.   
 
2.  The technical assistance (TA) for Phase IV (PSDI IV) will build on Phase III achievements 
across six core areas of focus: access to finance, business law reform, state-owned enterprise 
(SOE) reform, public–private partnerships (PPPs), competition and consumer protection, and the 
economic empowerment of women. PSDI IV will retain these areas of focus and also respond to 
climate change and labor mobility by incorporating these issues into relevant subprojects.3 
 
3.  A 2018 review of PSDI by ADB’s Independent Evaluation Department (IED) found that the 
first three phases helped provide several important inputs necessary for establishing modern, 
functioning private sectors in Pacific DMCs.4 While concluding that PSDI remained relevant and 
well-aligned  with  these  DMCs’  needs,  IED  made  recommendations  aimed  at  improving 
outcomes.5 These recommendations have been incorporated into PSDI IV.  PSDI IV is consistent 
with ADB’s Strategy 2030 and aligned with the strategic priorities of ADB’s Pacific Approach, 
2016–2020. The TA is included in the Pacific Regional Operations Business Plan, 2019–2021.6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Multiple and persistent constraints on private sector development. Despite progress, 
sustained engagement is needed to shift and remove the many barriers to healthier private 
sectors in Pacific DMCs. Most Pacific DMCs are remote, small in size and population, and 
vulnerable to shocks. Geographical dispersion and distance from major markets limit competition

Vanuatu.

and increase costs. Economies are narrow and rely heavily on the public sector and large, often 
struggling SOEs. Complex legislation and weak policies, along with human and institutional 
capacity constraints, raise the cost of doing business, make it hard for financiers and investors to 
assess risks, suppress business access to finance, and slow economic growth. Policy reforms 
have proven critical to improving these business environments so far. Private investment and 
growth trajectories have been lifted through PSDI I-III, and trade and connectivity within the Pacific 
and other markets has increased. Pacific DMCs are seeking further assistance under PSDI IV to 
accelerate and expand these reforms and address the numerous challenges that remain. 
 
5.  Limited  access  to  financial  services.  Businesses  in  the  Pacific  continue  to  face 
difficulties raising funds to meet their cash flow needs or expand their operations. Collateral 
frameworks have traditionally favored real assets. Local financial institutions lack risk-assessment 
capacity, and would-be borrowers are rarely able to develop bankable proposals. PSDI-led 
reforms have made it easier to secure credit using moveable assets by helping implement 
personal property securities acts (PPSAs) in nine Pacific DMCs. Further exploration is needed to 
determine how innovative financing instruments, including integrated fintech solutions, can be 
introduced to give entrepreneurs better access to credit at reduced costs. 
 
6.  Crowding out by underperforming state-owned enterprises. SOEs are a dominant 
presence in Pacific economies and often crowd the private sector out of commercially viable 
sectors and investment activities. Government subsidies for underperforming SOEs remain a 
drain on limited public funds.7 Although PSDI-supported reforms have improved the operations of 
SOEs in five Pacific DMCs, more legal, regulatory, and governance support is needed to further 
enhance the performance of SOEs and establish mechanisms for greater accountability and 
transparency. Greater private sector participation will also be explored. 
 
7.  Doing  business  still  difficult  and  costly.  Many  outdated  laws,  regulations,  and 
contracting arrangements in the Pacific do not meet the current needs of businesses or encourage 
micro and small businesses to join the formal economy. Samoa is the highest-placed Pacific 
country on the World Bank Group’s annual ease of doing business ranking.8 The Pacific lags 
behind other regions in the reform areas of the Doing Business 2019, namely starting a business, 
getting credit, enforcing contracts, and resolving insolvency.9 However, the report does recognize 
the reforms PSDI has helped implement to improve the region’s business environments, which 
are reflected by a rise by Pacific DMCs in its rankings, particularly in the areas of starting a 
business and getting credit (footnote 8). These reforms include PSDI work to help address often 
complex, unclear, and costly business laws that have made forming a business difficult and 
expensive. Business start-up times nonetheless remain long, and the costs are still high. To 
remove constraints on private sector development additional support is needed for further reforms 
that are backed by technology solutions.10

8.  Weak competition and consumer protection policies. Markets impaired by weak or 
ineffective competition hurt consumers, businesses, private sector development, and economic 
growth. Lack of competition and barriers to entry limit consumer choice and drive up costs for 
goods and services. Business opportunity is stifled, particularly for micro, small, and medium-
sized enterprises. Competition policy—with competition laws to implement it—is essential to 
ensuring competitive and healthy markets. This is true in markets where competition is nascent, 
SOEs dominate, or a handful of large private enterprises occupy multiple economic sectors. PSDI 
has started work in one DMC and will continue this work and expand to at least one more DMC. 
 
9.  Economic power and potential of women not yet fully realized. The vast potential of 
women to spur greater economic and inclusive growth remains largely unrealized in the Pacific. 
Women continue to be underrepresented in the formal economy due to discriminatory laws, 
financial constraints and inequitable access to resources imposed by social norms, customary 
practices, and structural barriers in the business sector. These factors together prevent women 
from fully participating in socioeconomic activities, engaging in sustainable livelihood strategies, 
accessing services, and leveraging economic benefits. Women in the Pacific often have limited 
ownership  and  little  control  over  assets  and  limited  access  to  training,  professional  skills 
development,  and  educational  opportunities. 11  Businesswomen  restricted  to  the  informal 
economy face other challenges. They generally have limited ability to avail government business 
opportunities, to enter into formal contracts, and to access financial services. Women and their 
businesses also have limited access to legal protections such as insurance or pension coverage. 
Once  they  enter  formal  business  enterprises  and  sectors,  women  often  face  inequitable 
governance  structures  that  limit  their  access  to  career  advancement,  leadership  training, 
promotions,  and  flexible  work  arrangements.  PSDI  has  implemented  gender  targeted  pilot 
projects, but will integrate economic empowerment of women across all work streams in PSDI IV. 
 
10.  Broad in-depth challenges in Papua New Guinea. The environment for private sector 
development  remains constrained  in  Papua  New  Guinea  (PNG)  as well  as  the  necessary 
conditions for supporting long-term economic growth that is sustainable and inclusive. PNG, the 
Pacific’s largest economy and most populous country, has been a significant user of PSDI 
expertise so far. Even though more than 80% of the country’s people depend on the agriculture 
sector for income, PNG’s farmers still have difficulty financing their operations. The country’s 
SOEs have extremely high debt levels, and decision making has been politicized. Poor SOE 
profitability has led to poor delivery of key infrastructure and services. Although approved, a 
competition policy is still to be implemented. Women face systemic legal and institutional barriers 
to full engagement in the economy. The enormous cost of foregoing the productive potential of 
one half of the population is exacerbated by the country’s difficult geography, widely dispersed 
population, infrastructure and service deficits, and dearth of economic opportunities.12 Australia 
provided dedicated cofinancing for PNG in phase III and this will continue in PSDI IV. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: inclusive, private sector-led economic growth 
 
11 ADB. 2018. Women and Business in the Pacific. Manila. 
12 Targeted Reform Program for Papua New Guinea under Pacific Private Sector Development Initiative, Phase IV 
(accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

4 
achieved in Pacific DMCs.13 The TA will have the following outcome: gender-inclusive enabling 
environment for private sector development improved.14  
 
12.  The  TA  will  continue  to  focus  on  the  six  core  areas  (para.  2)  with  the  economic 
empowerment of women mainstreamed through subprojects. Where appropriate and in response 
to Pacific government demand, the subprojects will incorporate ways to address climate change, 
the need to capture benefits from labor mobility, and the growing importance of increasing private 
sector participation in such industries as agriculture and tourism.  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
13.  Output 1: Access to inclusive business finance improved. PSDI has considerably 
broadened access to finance through its support for extensive financial sector reforms. These 
reforms have strengthened financial institutions and legal and regulatory frameworks, enhanced 
capacity, and developed new financial instruments and products to meet the evolving needs for 
private sector credit, particularly by women. PSDI IV will build on the secured transaction reforms 
that resulted in at least 70,000 new loans for small businesses and households after PPSAs were 
implemented in nine Pacific DMCs.15 With a particular focus on women, PSDI IV will (i) introduce 
secured transaction reforms in at least one more Pacific DMC and ensure that all registries 
capture  sex-disaggregated  data;  (ii)  establish  alternative  capital-raising  platforms,  including 
integrated fintech solutions in coordination with the Pacific Financial Inclusion Programme;16 (iii) 
strengthen selected state-owned banks by improving policies, regulations, and procedures for 
lending;  (iv)  improve  the  operations  of  national  provident  funds,  develop  their  investment 
management frameworks to international standards, and explore contribution options for labor 
scheme workers; (v) support financial institutions in developing financing products and services 
and improving financial literacy; and (vi) support central banks through the establishment of 
macroprudential and other financial sector stability frameworks.17 
 
14.  In delivering Output 1, the TA will (i) advise the Bank of PNG on macroprudential policy 
and instruments and help complete an initial financial sector stability report; (ii) work with the Bank 
of PNG, the Treasury, and the PNG Securities Commission to expand use of alternative capital-
raising platforms to boost access to finance for small business; (iii) assist the Bank of PNG in 
developing a regulatory framework for cryptoassets and initial coin offerings; and (iv) enable 
Women’s Micro Bank to expand credit to businesses owned by women.  
 
15.  Output  2:  Business  and  regulatory  environment  improved,  and  technology 
platforms introduced. PSDI has supported more than 60 initiatives in 11 Pacific DMCs to reform 
a wide range of laws governing business entry, business licensing, compliance, and foreign 
investment. In the four DMCs where PSDI implemented registries, this resulted in reducing the 
average time needed to register a business to less than 2 days and new company formation grew 
by an average of 88% in 2017. PSDI IV will build on the results by (i) reforming company laws 
and establish business registries in at least two more Pacific DMCs; (ii) providing additional

support  to  capture  the  benefits  of  improved  information  and  communication  technology 
connectivity in countries where registries already exist; and (iii) promoting women entrepreneurs 
through training. The TA will also ensure that business registries capture sex-disaggregated 
data—an important step since most women-owned businesses are currently informal. Where 
possible, legal changes will be accompanied by the establishment of online business registries, 
which also help governments implement the reforms. In PNG, a multipurpose online registry is 
planned that will support all aspects of business operations and link to key government agencies. 
 
16.  Output  3:  State-owned  enterprise  performance  improved  through  reforms, 
including privatization and public–private partnerships. The core infrastructure services 
largely provided by SOEs in the Pacific include airports, ports, broadcasting, telecommunication, 
water  supply  and  sanitation.  To  ensure  these  services  meet  the  needs  of  the  public  and 
businesses, SOEs need to operate within a commercial framework and be subject to disciplines 
found in the private sector. Of the 78 SOE reform initiatives PSDI has supported in 14 Pacific 
DMCs so far, 38 have involved PPPs. This work has helped strengthen SOEs and make them 
more profitable, reduced government fiscal transfers, and expanded and upgraded service 
delivery. PSDI IV will continue to provide legal, restructuring, and governance support for SOEs 
to (i) improve their regulatory frameworks and establish online portals that capture data on their 
performance, (ii) restructure and attract private investment, and (iii) increase the role of women 
through policy change and training in decision making. Where it is appropriate, transaction 
advisory services will support the SOE privatization and the structuring of PPPs.18  
 
17.  The TA will also respond to the PNG government’s request for an extensive reform 
program to improve the management and performance of the country’s struggling SOEs. The 
program envisaged includes (i) a new policy to guide overall future SOE reform; (ii) reforms to be 
adopted as law to improve SOE accountability, reporting, transparency, and overall governance; 
(iii) case-by-case reforms to put individual SOEs on the path to financial sustainability; and (iv) 
increased private sector participation through PPPs and privatization in SOE service delivery. 
 
18.  Output 4: Effective competition and consumer protection policies developed and 
implemented. PSDI IV will support competition policy and law reforms needed to develop private 
sectors, give the Pacific’s consumers better value for their money, offer small and medium-sized 
enterprises and other businesses a fair chance to enter markets and grow, and level the playing 
field  for  more  robust  economic  development.  PSDI  has  supported  the  development  and 
government endorsement of national competition policies in four Pacific DMCs so far, and PNG 
is now drafting the related implementing law. PSDI IV will (i) develop and implement policies and 
laws that support both fair competition and consumer protection in three more Pacific DMCs; (ii) 
ensure gender issues are incorporated in competition and consumer protection frameworks; and 
(iii) help build the capacity of competition commissions to develop guidelines and train officers. 
The focus in PNG will be on the formulation and passage of a competition bill. The TA will also 
work  to  help  PNG’s  Independent  Consumer  and  Competition  Commission  to  enhance  its 
complaints process, concentrating on better access for women consumers.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  ADB will be the executing agency. ADB’s Pacific Department, through its Pacific Liaison 
and Coordination Office in Sydney, will administer and implement the TA over 60 months from 1 
November 2019 to 31 October 2024. The Regional Director, Pacific Liaison and Coordination 
Office and the responsible project officer will monitor and oversee implementation of the TA. ADB 
will engage consultants and carry out procurement following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, 
as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration and staff instructions. TA 
proceeds will be disbursed in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Consultants recruited will comply with applicable ADB 
policies and guidelines. PSDI IV will use ADB’s Knowledge Nexus to ensure coordination with 
other ADB departments and offices providing private sector support in the Pacific and to store all 
knowledge products produced. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

21.  Consulting services. The TA will require 556 person-months of individual international 
consultants, 144 person-months of individual national consultants, and the services of consulting 
firms. Up to nine full-time consultants—six international (320 person-months), and three national 
(144 person-months)—will be recruited for the PSDI core team using individual consultant 
selection.22 Specialist short-term consultants and firms will be recruited to provide technical 
expertise for on-demand assignments in Pacific DMCs. The requirements and the length of 
engagement will vary based on the scope of work. The specialist individual consultants and firms 
will be recruited using a combination of individual consultant selection, quality-based selection, 
 
quality- and cost-based selection, and resource person contracting methods.
 
 
22.  Governance and coordination. A steering committee of representatives of ADB and 
cofinancing  partners  will  be  established  to  strengthen  governance  and  coordination  and 
implement one of the IED report recommendations (footnote 5).23 This committee will meet at 
least  every  6 months  to  review  accomplishments  and the forward  work  program.  The  TA 
consultants will work closely with ADB’s Pacific resident missions and country offices and comply 
with in-country mission guidelines.24 Within ADB, the previous phases of PSDI worked closely 
with the Private Sector Operations Department and the Office of Public-Private Partnership. PSDI 
shared its experience and knowledge with these departments to help them understand the 
intricacies  of  working  in  the  Pacific, forwarded  opportunities  for  potential  investments,  and 
undertook due diligence or pre-feasibility analysis to support potential transactions. Under PSDI 
IV, these arrangements will deepen as ADB strives for more private sector transactions in the 
Pacific and ADB staff are collocated with PSDI. 25 A part-time monitoring and evaluation specialist 
will  be  recruited  to  coordinate  evaluation  activities  and  ensure  that  evaluation  reports  are 
 
produced and completed in line with the individual subprojects’ work scope and timelines.
 
23.  Knowledge,  social  media,  and  websites.  PSDI  will  continue  to  produce  flagship 
publications to share best practices and establish a research basis for future subprojects.26 PSDI 
maintains a website and social media account and shares content with the ADB’s website and 
social media accounts.27 This will be expanded to partner websites and social media accounts. 
PSDI  IV  will  continue  to  maintain  and  upgrade  its  website  and  social  media  accounts. 
Arrangements for preserving this information after TA completion will be negotiated by the project 
officer with the PSDI partners and ADB’s Department of Communications. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION

equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis for the Pacific Private Sector Development Initiative, 
Phase IV, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Access to inclusive business finance improved  
1.1  Fully implement secured transaction reform underway in nine Pacific DMCs, support the installation of one secured 
transactions registry, and ensure all associated registries capture sex-disaggregated data (by July 2024) 
1.2  Develop, test, and help financial institutions adopt new financial products, including sector–value chain financing 
productsc and explore options to enable labor scheme workers to secure credit using their contracts (by July 2024) 
1.3  Support establishment of an alternative capital-raising platform, including integrated fintech solutions (by July 2024) 
1.4  Reform policies, regulations, and procedures for lending of state-owned banks (by July 2024) 
1.5  Develop investment frameworks and appropriate policies for national provident funds (by July 2024) 
1.6  Support central banks with financial sector stability frameworks, including macroprudential frameworks that 
promote gender and financial sector development (by July 2024) 
2.  Business and regulatory environment improved, and technology platforms introduced 
2.1  Reform commercial laws and establish new online business registries (by July 2024) 
2.2  Provide additional support to maximize the benefits of improved technology and connectivity to Pacific DMCs where 
registries already exist, including expanding cloud-based registries as a regional solution (by July 2024) 
2.3  Continuously encourage women’s engagement in the formal economy  
2.4  Collect sex-disaggregated data through PSDI-led online business registries (by July 2024) 
3.  State-owned enterprise performance improved through reforms, including privatization and public-private 
partnerships 
3.1  Develop and review SOE regulatory frameworks and improve governance practices and disclosure (by July 2024) 
3.2  Encourage restructuring and private investment, particularly in commercially viable renewable energy generation 
(by July 2024) 
3.3  Facilitate SOE privatization and PPPs (by July 2024) 
3.4  Encourage greater representation for women on SOE boards and management (by July 2024) 
4.  Effective competition and consumer protection policies developed and implemented 
4.1  Develop and implement national competition and consumer protection policies and legislation (by July 2024) 
4.2  Develop capacity-building training programs for competition and consumer commissions and ensure gender issues 
are considered in reformed competition and consumer laws (by July 2024)

Recruit consultants, including both long-term and short-term specialists (from November 2019, periodically) 
Manage consultant outputs related to performance targets and indicators (quarterly every year) 
Prepare and facilitate meetings and action items of the PSDI Steering Committee, and oversee mid-term review 
Monitor and evaluate PSDI initiatives, including through field visits; and track its performance against timelines and 
budget 
Liaise with financial institutions, private business entities, and government officials of participating Pacific DMCs 
Manage the communications of PSDI activities to ensure sufficient visibility of work including publishing flagship
